fulltext:
Reason: evaluate for DVTs
Admitting Diagnosis: CHEST PAIN/SHORTNESS OF BREATH
______________________________________________________________________________
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
 69 year old man with s/p cabg new PE  
  
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
 evaluate for DVTs                      
______________________________________________________________________________
                                FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  A 69-year-old man status post CABG with new PE.  Evaluate for
DVT.
COMPARISON:  Study from 2014-04-08.
BILATERAL UPPER EXTREMITY VENOUS ULTRASOUND:  There is limited evaluation of
the right internal jugular vein.  Grayscale and color Doppler sonography was
performed of the right and left cephalic, basilic, brachial, axillary and
subclavian veins, and of the left IJ vein.  The right IJ was not visualized
secondary to overlying bandages.
Again seen is distention of the left IJ, left cephalic, and right cephalic
with clot, without intraluminal flow.  There is also new occlusion of the left
superficial basilic vein.  The remainder of the venous structures demonstrates
normal flow, compressibility, and augmentation with normal waveforms.
IMPRESSION:  Persistent areas of intraluminal thrombus in the left IJ, and
within the superficial veins of the left and right cephalic veins, and new
thrombus in the superficial left basilic vein.

preview: IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of 35 cm single lumen PICC via the right basilic vein with its tip in the distal SVC; line ready for use.
fulltext:
TYPE: 'RADIOLOGY_REPORT'
DATE: 2014-4-20 9:45 AM
PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # Clip Number (Raiology) 9752
Reason: PICC for IV antibiotics                                     
Admitting Diagnosis: CHEST PAIN/SHORTNESS OF BREATH
********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
* 36569 PICC W/O State/Zipcode 85 FLUORO GUID PLCT/REPLCT/REMOVE*
* 76937 US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS                                            *
****************************************************************************
______________________________________________________________________________
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
  69 year old man s/p sternal rewire    
  
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
 PICC for IV antibiotics                
______________________________________________________________________________
                                FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  69-year-old status post sternal rewiring requiring IV
antibiotics.
RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. Last Name (STitle) 7276, with Dr. Last Name (STitle) 424,
the attending physician Name Initial (PRE) 6168.
PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  Patient was placed supine on the angiographic table.
Due to prior ultrasounds demonstrating extensive thrombus within the left
upper extremity, the right upper extremity was chosen for the PICC line.
Ultrasound demonstrated an appropriate right basilic vein which was punctured
with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle, through which a 0.018 guide wire was
advanced into the SVC.  A single lumen PICC trimmed to 35 cm and was advanced
under fluoroscopic guidance with its tip placed in the distal SVC.  Final
fluoroscopic image was taken to confirm tip placement.  Hard copy ultrasound
images were printed before and after venous puncture to confirm patency. There
are no immediate post-procedure complications.
IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of 35 cm single lumen PICC via the right
basilic vein with its tip in the distal SVC; line ready for use.

fulltext:
DATE: 2014-4-20 11:57 AM
CHEST (PA & LAT)                                               Clip # Clip Number (Radiology) 9753
Reason: evaluate effusions 
Admitting Diagnosis: CHEST PAIN/SHORTNESS OF BREATH
______________________________________________________________________________
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
    69 yoM s/p CABG last week now with chest pain at incision site and drainage, 
  no fevers. Also has gradual onset of SOB and fatigue.                          
       
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
 evaluate effusions                     
______________________________________________________________________________
                                FINAL REPORT
TYPE OF EXAMINATION:  Chest PA and lateral.
INDICATION:  Status post bypass surgery one week ago, now with chest pain at
incision site and drainage.  No fevers.  Also has gradual onset of shortness
of breath and fatigue.  Evaluate for effusions.
FINDINGS:  Frontal view demonstrates status post anterior chest wall
reconstruction with four bars of hardware in horizontal position.  Position of
previously described chest tubes is unchanged including right jugular approach
central venous line.  No pneumothorax is identified in the apical regions. 
Since the last preceding study of 4-18, apparently a right-sided PICC line
has been added, seen to terminate overlying the SVC some 3 cm above the level
of the carina.  The mild blunting of the left lateral pleural sinus persists
and the lateral view discloses also some blunting of the posterior pleural
sinuses representing postoperative findings.
Position of longitudinally directed multiple wire loops in the sternal area
appears unchanged and the row of subcutaneous clips is identified in the
anterior chest wall suture line, but no significant soft tissue changes can be
identified.
IMPRESSION:  Stable postoperative chest findings since 2014-4-18.

preview: IMPRESSION:\n1.  New large presternal fluid collection, with apparent communication with\nthe retrosternal space....
fulltext:
DATE: 2014-5-19 1:46 PM
CT CHEST W/CONTRAST                                             Clip # Clip Number (Radiology 9755
Reason: s/p bilat. pectoralis flaps, sternal plating with new fluid 
 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 
______________________________________________________________________________
UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
  69 yr old male with recent history of CABG presented with sternal debridement 
 /  unstable stenotomy.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
 s/p bilat. pectoralis flaps, sternal plating with new fluid collection          
______________________________________________________________________________
                                FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  Recent CABG, sternal debridement and repair, now with new fluid
collection.
TECHNIQUE:  MDCT was used to obtain contiguous axial images through the chest
after uneventful administration of 90 mL of Optiray IV contrast.  Standard and
lung algorithm images as well as coronal reformats were obtained.  This study
was compared with 2014-4-9.
CHEST CT WITH IV CONTRAST:  Several mediastinal plates are seen; separation of
the sternal halves is still seen, particularly in the inferior aspect.
Additionally, a new large presternal fluid collection is present, greatest in
the space between the topmost and secondmost plates.  In the superior and the
inferior aspect of the sternotomy, it appears to communicate freely with the
retrosternal space (series 2, image 40), though the amount of retrosternal
fluid is markedly diminished since the 2014-4-9 study.  There is no
significant stranding or gas within the fluid collection. The fluid collection
is somewhat broad- based, measuring approximately 3.0 cm A-P, 13.0 cm
transverse.
Small lymph nodes are noted in the mediastinum, the largest measuring 6 mm in
the precarinal region (2:21).  The pericardium is slightly thickened and
irregular, which is compatible with history of recent pericardial
intervention; the focus of pericardial calcification is unchanged.  The heart
is otherwise normal in size, with extensive coronary vascular calcifications.
Lungs are notable for mild centrilobular emphysema.  Additionally,
interstitial reticular opacities, most pronounced in the lung periphery and at
the bases, are slightly worse than the last examination.  A 4-mm lung nodule
is seen in the right upper lobe (3:28).  Bilateral pleural effusions are again
seen; the right is slightly larger than the previous, the left slightly
smaller; both remains small.  There is associated compressive atelectasis.
This study is not designed to examine the abdomen, however, multiple low-
density lesions in the liver are similar to the previous study; several of
these are too small to fully characterize; the largest is in the left lobe
measuring 23 mm, with fluid attenuation characteristics.  A left kidney lesion
measuring 10 mm represents a cyst.  The kidneys are incompletely imaged, but
fullness of the right collecting system is again seen.  No mass lesions are
identified in the imaged portion of the spleen or adrenals. There is a small
layering radiopaque gallstones 
BONE WINDOWS:  Aside from the sternal anatomy described above, no suspicious
sclerotic or lytic lesions are identified.  Large lipoma of the left
infraspinatus muscle is noted.
IMPRESSION:
1.  New large presternal fluid collection, with apparent communication with
the retrosternal space, but amount of retrosternal fluid is small and has
decreased since prior CT. Findings could represent postoperative seroma, but
infection should be considered in the appropriate clinical setting. No
discrete abscess identified.
2.  Bilateral pleural effusions, small, right greater than left.
3.  Worsening mild peripheral and basilar reticular and ground glass
opacities. Given their short interval worsening, a drug reaction should be
considered. Nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis would be less likely to have
such a rapid progression.
4.  Layering radiopaque gallstones.
5.  A right kidney cyst and liver cyst, unchanged.  Other numerous liver
lesions are too small to characterize, but similar in appearance to previous
study.
6.  Fullness of the right renal collecting system is incompletely imaged;
clinical correlation and/or imaging correlation recommended.
7.  4-mm right lung nodule, for which followup is recommended in one year to
document stability.

______________________________________________________________________________
                                FINAL REPORT
VENOUS ULTRASOUND
INDICATION:  History of upper extremity DVT, now with left neck swelling.
FINDINGS:  Comparison is made to the examination from 2014-4-20.  There is
persistent thrombus in the left internal jugular vein, which is not
compressible.  Some flow is demonstrated, suggesting partial recanalization.

basilic veins.

recanalization.

preview: A/P: this is a 69 yo M w/ h/o HTN and significant tobacco use, who presents for cardiac catheterization after abnormal perfusion scan, which revealed 3VD, prompting CABG.\n\nDischarge Disposition: Home with Service
fulltext:
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 Allergies: 
 Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
  
 Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 18**]  
 Chief Complaint:
 positive stress test ; chest pain during hypertension to 220/110

 
 Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
 Cardiac Catheterization [**3195-3-27**]
 CABGx5 (LIMA-LAD,SVG-Diag,SVG-OM1,SVG-OM2,SVG-PDA)[**3-31**]

  
 History of Present Illness:
 Mr. [**Known patient lastname 1652**] is a 69 yo M w/ h/o HTN and significant tobacco 
 use, who had a severe headache on [**3195-3-16**] without associated 
 symptoms (including weakness, visual changes), and was found to 
 be hypertensive to 220/110.  He was transferred via ambulence to 
 [**Hospital 51**] Hospital and in route complained of right sided chest 
 discomfort, associated with dyspnea and diaphoreiss. By report 
 he was administered SL NTG and nitro paste with improvement in 
 BP and chest discomfort.  He subsequently underwen ETT with 
 pMIBI which demonstrated a perfusion deficit at rest and was 
 referred to [**Hospital1 83**] for cardiac catheterization and renal artery 
 angiogram. 
 .
 Mr. [**Known patient lastname 1652**] also reports decreased exercise tolerance over the 
 past several months - previously he would be able to climb 
 several flights of stairs without difficulty; he currently gets 
 extremely dypsneic after 10 steps (<1 flight); no associated CP, 
 N, or diahphoresis.  He denies orthopnea and PND.
 .
 He denies history of angina or CAD.
 .
 Mr. [**Known patient lastname 1652**] [**Last Name (Titles) 22**] cardiac catheterization today and was 
 found to have 3VD, and a CABG is now planned.  He took a dose of 
 plavix this morning.
 .
 ROS: denies recent illness, fevers, hematuria, melena, bloody 
 stools, abdominal pain, LE swelling.  Reports 8lb intentional 
 weight loss (healthier diet)
 Referred for CABG .
  
 Past Medical History:
 HTN
 GERD
 Bladder ca s/p excision x 2 and the BCG treatment
 Syncopal episodes x 3 (episodes accompanied by diaphoresis and
 nausea) with the last episode many years ago
 H/O pneumonia x 3
 Depression
 Chronic back problems including disc herniation, s/p disc 
 surgery
 Anxiety
 COPD
 BPH
  
 Social History:
 Married, lives with his wife, 5 children.  He is a retired truck
 driver and currently helps out in his son's restaurant.  
 +tobacco 1ppd x 55 years.  Occasional EtOH. No illicits
  
 Family History:
 Noncontributory (h/o cancer)
  
 Physical Exam:
 138/61  51  16  100% RA  5'[**98**] Wt:220 lbs
 Gen: NAD, smiling
 HEENT: aniecteric, PERRL, EOMI, MMM, no JVD, no bruits
 CV: regular rhythm, ~60, no M/R/G
 Chest: CTAB
 Abd: Soft, NT/ND
 R Groin: dressing C/D/I, no bruit or thrill
 Ext: 2+ DP pulses bilaterally
 Neuro: A&Ox3, fluent speech, normal ambulation, MAE
  
 Pertinent Results:
 [**3195-3-27**] 10:33AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-4.50* Hgb-12.6* Hct-35.9* 
 MCV-80* MCH-27.9 MCHC-35.0 RDW-15.2 Plt Ct-193
 [**3195-3-27**] 10:33AM BLOOD Glucose-98 UreaN-21* Creat-1.0 Na-137 
 K-4.1 Cl-107 HCO3-24 AnGap-10
 [**3195-3-27**] 10:33AM BLOOD ALT-8 AST-12 AlkPhos-63 TotBili-0.5
 [**3195-3-27**] 10:33AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.1
 .
 Recent testing:
 [**3195-3-21**]: Echo showed a normal LV size and function.  EF of 
 60-65%.  The valves were all normal with trace TR.  Pulmonary 
 systolic pressure was estimated to be 30-35%. [**3195-3-17**]: Nuclear 
 stress test where the patient exercised for 6 minutes 57 seconds 
 on [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1078**] protocol stopping due to shortness of breath and leg 
 pain.  He achieved 68% of his predicted target heart rate.  He 
 did not develop any arrhythmias or chest pain.  The nuclear 
 images demonstrated a normal sized left ventricle. There was a 
 moderate sized reversible perfusion abnormality involving the 
 anteroapical and septal portion left ventricle. There was also a 
 question of a small reversible abnormality involving the 
 inferolateral portion left ventricle.  The left ventricular wall 
 motion was normal.  The LVEF was 62%.
 .
 [**3195-3-27**] Cardiac Catheterization
 COMMENTS:      
 1.  Coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed 
 severe three vessel coronary artery disease.  The left main 
 coronary artery had no angiographically apparent flow limiting 
 stenoses.  The LAD was ectatic proximally and occluded in the 
 mid segment after a small diagonal.  The LCX had a 90% stenosis 
 of the OM1 proximally and a 50% followed by a 70% stenosis in 
 the proximal and mid segment of the OM2. The RCA had a 90% 
 stenosis in the mid PDA. 
 2.  Limited resting hemodynamics revealed mildly to moderately 
 elevated left sided filling pressures (LVEDP was 18 mm Hg).  
 Systemic arterial pressure was normal (aortic pressure was 
 121/73 mm Hg).  There was no significant gradient across the 
 aortic valve upon pullback of the catheter from the left 
 ventricle to the ascending aorta. 
 3.  Left ventriculography revealed a contrast calculated 
 ejection 
 fraction of 65%.  No mitral regurgitation was noted. 4.  
 Bilateral selective renal angiography demonstrated widely patent 
 renal arteries. 
 FINAL DIAGNOSIS:     
 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 
 2. Normal left ventricular systolic function. 
 3. Mildly to moderately elevated left sided filling pressures. 
 4. No angiographically apparent renal artery stenosis. 
 .
 Pulmonary Function Tests:
 [**3195-4-4**] 06:25AM BLOOD WBC-7.3 RBC-3.17* Hgb-9.1* Hct-26.3* 
 MCV-83 MCH-28.7 MCHC-34.6 RDW-15.5 Plt Ct-201#
 [**3195-4-4**] 06:25AM BLOOD Plt Ct-201#
 [**3195-4-4**] 06:25AM BLOOD Glucose-101 UreaN-14 Creat-1.3* K-5.1

 Cardiology Report ECHO Study Date of [**3195-3-31**]   
  
   
   
 PATIENT/TEST INFORMATION: 
 Indication: Chest pain. Coronary artery disease. Hypertension.  
 Status: Inpatient 
 Date/Time: [**3195-3-31**] at 10:41 
 Test: TEE (Complete) 
 Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler 
 Contrast: None 
 Tape Number: 2007AW2-: 
 Test Location: Anesthesia West OR cardiac 
 Technical Quality: Adequate 
 
 
 
 
 REFERRING DOCTOR: DR. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] 
   
 MEASUREMENTS:  
 Left Ventricle - Septal Wall Thickness: *1.5 cm (nl 0.6 - 1.1 cm) 
 Left Ventricle - Ejection Fraction: 45% to 50% (nl >=55%) 
 Aorta - Ascending: *3.7 cm (nl <= 3.4 cm) 
 Aortic Valve - Peak Velocity: 1.4 m/sec (nl <= 2.0 m/sec) 
   
 INTERPRETATION:  
       
 Findings:  
   
 LEFT ATRIUM: Normal LA size. No spontaneous echo contrast in the body of the LA. No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus in the body of the [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] LAA.  
   
 RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. A catheter or pacing wire is seen in the RA and extending into the RV. No ASD by 2D or color Doppler.  
   
 LEFT VENTRICLE: Mild symmetric LVH with normal cavity size. Mild symmetric LVH. Normal LV cavity size. Mild regional LV systolic dysfunction. No LV mass/thrombus. Mildly depressed LVEF. Transmitral Doppler and TVI c/w normal LV diastolic function. No resting LVOT gradient.  
   
 LV WALL MOTION: Regional LV wall motion abnormalities include: anterior apex - hypo;  
   
 RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.  
   
 AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Mildly dilated ascending aorta. Normal aortic arch diameter. Simple atheroma in aortic arch. Normal descending aorta diameter. Simple atheroma in descending aorta.
 
 
 AORTIC VALVE: Three aortic valve leaflets. Mildly thickened aortic valve leaflets. No AS. Trace AR.  
   
 MITRAL VALVE: Normal mitral valve leaflets with trivial MR. [**Last Name (Titles) 1653**] annular calcification. No MS. Physiologic MR (within normal limits).  
   
 TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR.  
   
 PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Normal pulmonic valve leaflets with physiologic PR.  
   
 PERICARDIUM: Trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.  
   
 GENERAL COMMENTS: A TEE was performed in the location listed above. I certify I was present in compliance with HCFA regulations. No TEE related complications. The patient received antibiotic prophylaxis. The TEE probe was passed with assistance from the anesthesioology staff using a laryngoscope. The patient was under general anesthesia throughout the procedure.  
    
 Conclusions:  
 PRE-CPB: 
 1.The left atrium is normal in size. No spontaneous echo contrast is seen in the body of the left atrium. No spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of the left atrium or left atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler.  
 2. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with 
 normal cavity size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is mild regional left ventricular  systolic dysfunction with apical anterior hypokinesis.. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Overall left ventricular systolic function is  mildly depressed. Transmitral Doppler and tissue velocity imaging are consistent with normal LV diastolic function.  
 3. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal.  
 4. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated at a maximum of 3.7. There are simple  atheroma in the aortic arch. There are simple atheroma in the descending  thoracic aorta.  
 5. There are three aortic valve leaflets. The aortic valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen.  
 6. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. Physiologic mitral regurgitation is seen (within normal  
 limits).  
 7. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. POST-CPB: Patient is on phenylephrine infusion. Preserved biventricular  systolic function with improvement of the anteroapical hypokinetic segment. LVEF now 55%. Trace MR. [**Last Name (Titles) 1654**] is normal post decannulation.  
   
 Electronically signed by [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1655**], MD on [**3195-3-31**] 15:02.

READING PHYSICIAN:   
  
   
 (07-06179G) 
    RADIOLOGY  Final Report

 CHEST (PA & LAT)  [**3195-4-3**] 11:20 AM

 CHEST (PA & LAT)

 UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
 69 yoM s/p CABG and CT removal 
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
 r/o ptx 
 TWO VIEW CHEST OF [**3195-4-3**].

 COMPARISON: [**3195-3-31**]

 INDICATION: Chest tube removal.

 Various lines and tubes have been removed since the prior radiograph, and a very small left apical pneumothorax has developed. Cardiac and mediastinal contours are within normal limits for postoperative status of the patient. Small pleural effusions and minor bibasilar atelectasis are noted. These findings are superimposed upon subtle likely more chronic peripheral and basilar interstitial lung disease.

 On the lateral view, small air-fluid level is present in the retrosternal region likely representing an anterior hydropneumothorax, and additional air is present in the retrosternal region, an expected postoperative finding given the time interval since surgery.

 IMPRESSION: Small left pneumothorax following tube removal. 
 Bibasilar atelectasis and small pleural effusions.

fulltext:
Admission note
 O: pt presented to osh w chest pressure. R/I ant mi transf to [**Hospital1 **] for pci.CC- 1 vessel disease  100% occlus to lad-> angiojetx2 and placemnt of drug eluting stent to lad.Freq hypotensive episodes during cath w aivr prompted rt fem iab placemnt for support.
 Adm to csru in sr w freq pac's /multifocal pvc's on integrilin.VEA ^'d to runs vt x2->HO updated & lytes corrected w mag sulfate 2gm & kcl 40 meq ivpb. Iabp rt fem 1:2 w fair augmentation despite adjustment, distal pulses initially only by  doppler now palpable. Site oozy for lg amts ss drng, pressure directly over site x 2 to achieve hemostasis.
 Resp status: bbs clear but diminsh bibas lt> rt. Dry cough at times. O2 pleth difficult to pickup at times. Np at 4 lpm w adeq sats.

 Neuro status: aaoriented, pleasant, talkative(anxious) gentleman. Very talkative initially now resting in naps. Limited movement d/t iabp but pt moving and follows commands.Perl 3mm brisk react.Wife in to visit w pt briefly post cath. Icu visitation policy literature given to wife.

 Gi status: abd soft,flat,+bowel snds & passing flatus. Denies gi upset, on h2 blocker po.

 Gu status: condom cath in place & vd x 1 150cc urine.

 Iv access: bilat antecub lines. Rt fem iab and pa line w gd waveform.Venous sheath in place and oozy at site.

 Heme/ID: hct stable at 38. wbc 15 w low grade temps
 A/P: Wean iab as tol once stabilized. Recheck lytes.Log roll only in view of iab rt fem.Cycle ck's and labs as ordered. Notify ho if vea persists after lyte repletion. Pt teaching re: cardiac rehab once pt adeq rested, less anxious.

fulltext:
pt arrived from [**Location **] @ 1230 with IABP @ 1:2 & integrilin gtt 
 cv: hr nsr, occasional pvc's & short runs([**4-4**] bts) of v-tach, ho aware, IABP changed to 1:3, fick ci 2.4 on 1:3 & IABP dc'd by fellow @ 1510, swan & r fem venous sheath also dc'd, no active hematoma noted with sheath pull, old small hematoma noted, on po lopressor, to start po captopril this pm, distal pulses by doppler

 resp: on 2 l np, bs+ all lobes & clear, sat 99-100, no sob or resp distress

 gi: npo for IABP dc, to start cardiac diet this pm, no c/o nausea, no stool, po ranitidine

 gu: condom cath on, voiding clear yellow urine

 neuro: A&Ox3, follows commands, moving all extremities

 other: d5w with 150 meq na bicarb/liter up @ 100cc/hr x 1 liter for post cath fluids, family in & updated on pt's condition, integrilin gtt to be dc'd @ 1900 & heparin gtt started @ 600u/hr, ck, troponin sent @ 1500, pt given iv ativan for anxiety for IABP dc

 plan: contniue to monitor in ccu overnoc, cardiac echo, tx to floor tomorrow if stable

CCU progress 3p-7p\n VSS. IABP + PA line d/c'd by cards fellow. Pt given ativan 0.5mg for anxiety + slept part of evening. Pressure dsg applied to site for small ooze. area ecchymotic and small hematoma noted 3cm below groin stick which was there prior to sheath removal. \n wife in to visit. assisted w/ dinner. to lie flat until midnite (8hrs d/t large IABP sheath). faint palpable DP pulses, [**1-31**]+PT.

fulltext:
CCU progress note 7a-7p
 Uneventful day. VSS. OOB to chair. ambulating in room. PT consult ordered.  SEE TRANSFER NOTE.

 CARDIAC: Increased Lopressor to 25mg TID w/ HR still SR 80s-90s - next dose to be increased to Lopressor 37.5mg TID. Captopril 6.25mg TID.  SBP 88-100s. no c/o CP. no runs of VT noted today. R groin ecchymotic w/ hematoma marked, no increase noted. to be started on coumadin tonite.

      RESP: LS clear. RA. sats 94-95%

 GI/GU: voiding clear yellow. taking po diet well. +BS. no BM.

 NEURO: A+Ox3. no c/o. pleasant + cooperative. wife calling, updated + talking to husband.

 PLAN: transfer to stepdown when bed available. cont' cardiac meds. monitor tele. monitor VS.

Admission Date:  [**2012-1-20**]              Discharge Date:   [**2012-1-26**]
	Date of Birth:     [**2544-9-23**]		Sex:M
	
	'Service': MEDICINE
	
	Allergies: 
	Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
	
		Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 340**] 
	Chief Complaint:
		Transferred from outside hospital for coronary and carotid cath
		
	Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
		carotid cath
	coronary cath

		
		History of Present Illness:
		64 yr old hypertensive, diabetic male with CAD s/p CABG '[**01**] and b/l carotid disease transferred from OSH after an episode of chest pain and aphasia. He was in his USOH until [**2012-1-19**] when at noon he developed substernal chest 'burning' while sitting at his office.  He noticed that his speech was slurred and 'the words wouldn't come out.' When his wife called him she noted that his words 'made no sense' 'he was saying nonsense.'  She thought he might have been hypoglycemia and gave him some coke, after which his symptoms improved.  They called EMS and were taken to [**Hospital **] Hospital.  A Head CT was   (-) for bleed and Trop-I+ 0.87. Ck 200.  He received 2 doses of 1 mg/kg lovenox and was transferred to [**Hospital1 83**].

		He had LAD stent in [**Hospital1 83**]. A few days later, he has RCA stented and has myoclonic jerk, NOT seizure in the cath lab per neurology attending

		ROS: (-) SOB/Palp/Edema/N/V/Weakness/numbness/HA.

	
		Past Medical History:
	##CAD s/p CABG in [**2601**] with EF 50% by LVG.  He has chest pain with lifting boxes.  LIMA>>LAD, SVG>>Diag -[**9-20**] ETT Thal for 2 minutes with HR 130, 2 mm horizontal lateral ST depressions.
		##non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus x 10 years.
		##hypertension
		##hypercholesterolemia
		##Stroke/TIA with no residual defects.  Carotid U/S in 10/04 with right ICA occlusion and left 80-99% stenosis.  Followed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] (cardiology) and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 11742**] (vasc [**Doctor First Name 668**]).  
		## B/L Claudication 
		 
		Social History:
		Quit smoking 25 years ago.  No EtOH.  Works as a mechanic.  
		Lives with wife.  2 adopted children.
		 
		Family History:
		Mother MI at 60
		 
		Physical Exam:
		Temp: afebrile BP:120/82  HR:60  RR:12  O2:99 RA
		Gen: NAD,  A/O x 3
		HEENT: PEARLA.  EOMI.  OP w/o lesions.
		CV:  RR.  Soft II/VI systolic murmur at LLSB.  JVD flat.  
		Sternotomy incision c/d/i.
		Pulm: CTA B/L
		ABD: S/NT/ND  
		Ext: no edema.  s/p vein graft incision c/d/i.  1+DP/PT
		Neuro: Motor [**3-23**] at all flexors/extensors.  Sensation: GI to light touch and pinprick.  [**Doctor First Name **] intact.  FTN intact.  CNII-XII: GI
		 
		Pertinent Results:
		AT OSH:

		Na:138, K:4.3, BUN:20, Cr:1.4, INR:0.9, WBC:10.1  Hgb:14.6, 
		Plt:171

			ECG: NSR at 56. Qs in III, F.  J-pt elevation in V1, V2, II, F.  
		Lateral TWI (dynamic).  Nl Axis/intervals.
		CXR: No CP processes

		[**2012-1-19**]: Chronic Right Occipital Cortical Infarct, chronic deep 
		white matter infarction due to small vessel disease, small 
		lacunar infarct in left thalamus.
		cath [**1-25**]:
		1. Significant native coronary artery disease.
		2. Severe bilateral internal carotid artery disease.
		3. Arterial disease in the left subclavian and bilateral 
		vertebrals
		4. Successful placement of self-expanding stent in left ICA.
		5. Successful employment of AccuNet distal embolic protection.
		6. Self-limited, brief myotoclonus event.
		COMMENTS: 
		1. Limited coronary angiography demonstrated a right dominant system with left main and severe native vessel disease. The LMCA had an ostial 60% lesion. The proximal and midvessel LAD had diffuse calcific disease. The distal LAD filled via a LIMA which was not selectively engaged. The D1 branch was totally occluded. The LCx had mild diffuse disease. The RCA and bypass grafts were not successfully engaged.
		2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed a central blood pressure of 132/57 mmHg and a left CFA pressure of 101/67 mmHg. The mean gradient was 3 mmHg.
		3. Retrograde access of the left common femoral artery was obtained for selective carotid, vertebral, and coronary angiography. The thoracic aorta had a Type I arch. The bilateral subclavian arteries had mild proximal disease. The left subclavian artery had a 50% lesion in the origin with a peak to peak gradient of 20 mmHg.
		4. The right vertebral artery was small and diminutive with a total occlusion at the base of the skull before entering the brain. The left vertebral artery was large and was noted to have a 60% origin lesion and filled the basilar and the cerebellar arteries. The contralateral PCA filled from the vertebral but the ipsilateral (left) PCA was not seen.
		5. The right common carotid artery was without disease but the ICA was totally occluded. The left common carotid artery was without disease but the ICA had diffuse tubular 80% disease. The left ICA filled the ipsilateral ACA and MCA as well as the contralateral ACA and MCA via a large ACOM.
		6. Successful placement of a [**4-26**] x 40 mm Acculink stent in the left ICA postdilated with a 4.5 mm balloon. Final angiography demonstrated no residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection, and normal flow (See PTCA Comments).
		7. Transient, self-limited myoclonic event during postdilation which was though not likely to represent seizure activity.
		8. Successful Perclose of the left femoral arteriotomy site at the conclusion of the procedure without complications.
		Cath at OSH [**8-22**]: multiple tight stenoses of the proximal LAD and proximal D1. Proximal D2 occluded. RCA proximally occluded. LIMA to LAD patent, svg to diag could not be visualized and was presumed occluded. Left carotid patent, right carotid occluded. 

		cardiac cath [**2012-1-23**]
		1. Three vessel coronary artery disease.
		2. Rotation atheterectomy of the proximal LAD.
		3. Unsuccessful attempt at PTCA/stenting of the D1.
		COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography revealed a right dominant system. The RCA was not injected. The SVgs and the LIMA were not injected. The LMCA had a 60% ostial stenosis. The proximal LAD [**Last Name (un) **] 80% calcific stenosis. The distal LAD was filling via a LIMA (there was competitive flow). The D1 had a 80% calcific stenosis at the origin. The LCX had mild diffuise disease.
		2. Unsuccessful attempt at PTCA/stenting of the D1 due to inability to cross despite using multiple wires. Rotational atherectomy was performed in the LAD in an attempt to modify the LAD lesion and allow
		crossing inro the D1 (See PTCA comments).

		carotid series [**2012-1-23**]:
		REASON: Known carotid atherosclerosis, pre-op for stenting. 
		 
		FINDINGS: Duplex evaluation was performed of both carotid arteries. Significant plaque was identified on the right. There is no flow in internal carotid artery including power Doppler technique. Of note there is no study for comparison. 
		 
		On the left, significant mostly soft appearing homogeneous plaque is identified in the internal carotid artery. Of note it appears to extend fairly distally in the cervical internal carotid artery. 
		 
		On the right, peak systolic velocities are 52, 72 in the CCA, ECA respectively. 
		 
		On the left, in the internal carotid artery the peak systolic over diastolic velocity is 361/123. In the remainder of the vessel the peak systolic velocities are 54, 584 in the CCA, ECA respectively. The ICA-CCA ratio is 6. This is consistent with an 80-99% stenosis.

He was admitted for coronary and carotid cath.Patient had cardiac catheterization on [**2012-1-25**] and

Successful placement of self-expanding stent in left ICA and successful employment of AccuNet distal embolic protection. Patient was admitted briefly to CCU for observation overnight. 	      64 year old man with known b/l carotid stenosis awaiting carotid stenting.

	      Please evaluate b/l carotids with doppler.                                      
	     ______________________________________________________________________________
	                                     FINAL REPORT
	     CAROTID SERIES COMPLETE:

 REASON:  Known carotid atherosclerosis, pre-op for stenting.

 FINDINGS:  Duplex evaluation was performed of both carotid arteries.
	     Significant plaque was identified on the right.  There is no flow in internal
	     carotid artery including power Doppler technique.  Of note there is no study
	     for comparison.

 On the left, significant mostly soft appearing homogeneous plaque is
	     identified in the internal carotid artery.  Of note it appears to extend
	     fairly distally in the cervical internal carotid artery.

 On the right, peak systolic velocities are 52, 72 in the CCA, ECA
	     respectively.

 On the left, in the internal carotid artery the peak systolic over diastolic
	     velocity is 361/123.  In the remainder of the vessel the peak systolic
	     velocities are 54, 584 in the CCA, ECA respectively.  The ICA-CCA ratio is 6.
	     This is consistent with an 80-99% stenosis.

 There is antegrade flow in both vertebral arteries.

 IMPRESSION:

 Occluded right internal carotid artery.  Of note there is no prior study for
	     comparison.  On the left, there is a significant plaque with an 80-99% carotid
	     stenosis.

fulltext:
DATE: [**2012-1-25**] 9:52 AM
	     CHEST (PA & LAT)                                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7970**]
	     Reason: r/o pneumonia                                               
	     Admitting Diagnosis: CHEST PAIN;TIA
	     ______________________________________________________________________________
	     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
	      64 year old man with fever & rising WBC                                         
	     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
	      r/o pneumonia                                                                   
	     ______________________________________________________________________________
	                                     FINAL REPORT
	     INDICATION:  Rising white blood cell count and fever.

 No prior radiographs for comparison.

 PA AND LATERAL CHEST RADIOGRAPHS:  The patient is post-median sternotomy.
	     There are aortic calcifications.  The heart size is at upper limits of normal.
	     The pulmonary vasculature has a normal appearance.  The lungs are clear
	     without focal consolidations.  There is no effusion or pneumothorax.  A
	     solitary calcified granuloma is seen in the right apex.

 IMPRESSION:  No findings of CHF or pneumonia.

CCU Nursing Progress Note 1900-0700
		S: 'I feel pretty good'
		O: Please see careview for complete VS/additional objective data.
		In brief this is a 54 yo gentleman w/ significant hx for HTN, NIDDM w/ CAD s/p CABG [**01**] and carotid ds. Pt was transferred from OSH after episode of CP, blurred vision and aphasia w/borderline troponin elevation and nonspecific ant/lat ST-Twave changes. ? TIA vs hypoglycemia. Ct infarct. Cath revealed 3VD. S/P rotational artherectomy of LAD following unsuccessful PTCA of calcified D1. On [**1-25**] pt underwent stent to TO R ICA. Pt tolerated intervention well although pt was noted to have a single myoclonus event post dilitation but not likely true seizure but a result of reperfusion.
		MS: Completely neurologically intact. No deficits noted. MAE. PEARL. 3mm in size. Brisk in response. Repositions self. Dangled and sat at bedside while urinating. Tolerated well. Pt denies any additional blurriness/ aphasia etc.

CV: Pt arrived to CCU VSS. NIBP goal per HO 120-160. Neo/Nitro ordered but never needed overnoc. SBP started to trend down and while asleep noted to be 96. Team notified and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 241**] reestablished goals that as long as SBP >90 not to start pressors. HR 58-68. No ectopy. Transient drop to ^40s noted rarely. NIBP 96-156/42-55. MAPs>60. Left groin site CDI. Cont post stent treatment includingDSD remains intact. Distal pulses dopplerable.

Resp: Occ noted for apnea. O2 sats briefly noted at 90% while asleep. Placed pt on NC 2L w/ good effect. RR 15-23. Pt denies SOB. O2 sats 97-100%. Good cough. No secretions. Pt c/o sinus stuffiness. Ordered for Afrin but didn't arrive to unit until pt was asleep. Pt denies SOB.
		GI/GU: Abd soft/obese. +BS. No stool. Minimal intake. + BS. No stool. 
DTV upon arrival to CCU. Pt received IVFB 250cc NSx2 for lack of output and in attempt to improve SBP. Condom catheter remains on. Pt -225cc and remains + LOS. BUN/CR 16/1.1.
		ID: Cont to have low grade temp. Tmax 100.4 po. Tylenol 650mg x1 given. No abx at present. WBC 13.5.
		SKin: Intact.

Access: 1 PIV. Pt has h/o PVD. Difficult to obtain access.

A/P: Significant cardiac hx. 3vd recent  catheterization and rot artherctomy of LAD. Unable to cross wire and address D1 80% lesion. ? TIA upon admission to OSH. CT positive for infarct. R ICA TO and L ICA 80-99%. S/P successfully stenting of R ICA. To CCU for observation. Pt remained hemodynamically stable  overnoc. Cont to support pt and family. Advance diet and activity as tolerated. ? Call out to the floor today.

 REASON:  Narrowing of carotid artery.

 STUDY #2, ARTERIAL DOPPLER CLAUDICATION.

 FINDINGS:  Duplex evaluation was performed of both carotid arteries.  The
	     right internal carotid artery is occluded.  On the left, a carotid stent is
	     visualized and is patent but has significant elevated velocities as will be
	     described below.

 On the right, peak systolic velocities are 45, 115 in the CCA and ECA
	     respectively.

 On the left in the internal carotid artery, the peak systolic over diastolic
	     velocity is 319/124.  In the remainder of the vessel, the peak systolic
	     velocities are 56, 123 in the CCA, ECA respectively.  The ICA to CCA ratio is
	     5.6.  This is consistent with an 80% to 99% stenosis.

 There is antegrade flow in both vertebral arteries.

 Although velocities in the left internal carotid artery stent are consistent
	     with a high-grade stenosis, this is likely falsely elevated to both to the
	     stent and also to the contralateral occlusion.

 IMPRESSION:  Occluded right internal carotid artery.  On the left, the stent
	     is patent, but the velocities are elevated, consistent with an 80% to 99%
	     stenosis.  However, as stated above, that is likely to be artifactually
	     elevated.

 Doppler evaluation was performed of both lower extremity arterial systems at
	     rest and with exercise.  Exercise consist of toe-ups for 1 minute and 45
	     seconds.  Pain developed in both calves at 1 minute.

 On the right, Doppler tracings are triphasic at all levels from the femoral to
	     the dorsalis pedis artery.  The ankle brachial index is 1.06.  Pulse volume
	     recordings are maintained to the calf and show drop off at the ankle and
	     metatarsals.  After exercise, the ABI dropped to 0.47 and the waveforms in the
	     common femoral artery becomes monophasic.

 On the left, Doppler tracings are triphasic at the femoral level only.  They
	     are monophasic below.  The ankle brachial index is 0.69.  With exercise, this
	     decreases to 0.27.  Pulse volume recordings are dampened at low thigh level
	     and approximately 7 mm at the metatarsals.

 IMPRESSION:  Significant aortobiiliac and likely left superficial femoral
	     artery occlusive disease.  In addition, there may be proximal femoral artery
	     disease on the right.  With very limited exercise, there is a severe decrement
	     in bilateral ABI.

preview:
CONCLUSION: No significant change as compared to the two prior available
	     comparison from March and [**2012-7-20**], with:
	     1. a known occlusion of the right internal carotid artery, and
	     2. status post stent placement in the region of the left carotid bulb, and
	     increased velocities in the mid and distal portion of the left internal
	     carotid artery consistent with a stenosis estimated between 80 and 99% in
	     diameter (closer to 80%)
fulltext:
DATE: [**2012-12-8**] 10:17 AM
	     CAROTID SERIES COMPLETE                                         Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 7973**]
	     Reason: history carotid stent for surveillance
	     ______________________________________________________________________________
	     UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION:
	      64 year old man with carotid stent for surveillance
	     REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
	      history carotid stent for surveillance
	     ______________________________________________________________________________
	                                     FINAL REPORT
	     INDICATION: Surveillance of carotid artery stent in a 64-year-old man.

 COMPARISON: There were two available comparisons, from [**1-23**] and [**7-25**], 2005, respectively. They showed a stable, 80-99% diameter narrowing of the
	     left internal carotid artery and a known, complete occlusion of the right
	     internal carotid artery.

 TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: Duplex ultrasonography was performed at the level of
	     the cervical portions of the bilateral carotid and vertebral arteries.

 The chronic occlusion of the right internal carotid artery is found again,
	     with no intraluminal flow detectable by spectral or color Doppler imaging. The
	     peak systolic velocities in the right common and external carotid arteries are
	     57 and 109 cm/second, respectively.

 The left carotid stent is visualized at the level of the internal and common
	     carotid arteries. The peak systolic velocities in the left internal, common,
	     and external carotid arteries are 291, 53, and 446 cm/second. The end-
	     diastolic velocities are 100 cm/second in the left internal carotid artery and
	     25 cm/sec in the left common carotid artery. The acceleration in the
	     internal carotid artery seems localized to its mid and distal cervical
	     portions but spares its ostium. Systolic turbulences are found in the distal
	     portion of the left internal carotid artery. These values and findings are
	     again consistent with a luminal narrowing between 80 and 99% in diameter
	     (probably closer to 80%.).

 Antegrade flow is found in the bilateral vertebral arteries, in their
	     intertransverse portions.

 CONCLUSION: No significant change as compared to the two prior available
	     comparison from March and [**2012-7-20**], with:
	     1. a known occlusion of the right internal carotid artery, and
	     2. status post stent placement in the region of the left carotid bulb, and
	     increased velocities in the mid and distal portion of the left internal
	     carotid artery consistent with a stenosis estimated between 80 and 99% in
	     diameter (closer to 80%).
